Award.AwardTitle: UNH Manchester Scholars in Science and Technology Engage and Discover

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This project provides scholarships for 36 STEM bachelor degree students, with recruitment focused specifically on underrepresented groups. The targeted disciplines are Biology, CIS, and Engineering Technology. The goals of the program are to 1) develop and emphasize new science, technology, and professional programs, 2) establish campus to community outreach, 3) increase the level of need and merit based financial aid, 4) develop First Year Programming to integrate academic enrichment and co-curricular activities, 5) increase community engagement activities, 6) create a collegial and supportive community, and 7) build partnerships with other academic institutions, community organizations, and businesses.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project “UNH Manchester Scholars in Science and Technology Engage and Discover” (UNHM-SST) served 69 scholars who shared a large diversity of academic preparedness, life experiences, and cultural backgrounds, and were constrained by financial resources and time (full-time enrollment, jobs, and family and community responsibilities). Recruitment specifically focused on underrepresented groups who could not afford to attend college. The goals of the program were to 1) develop and emphasize new science and technology programs; 2) increase the level of need and merit based financial aid; 3) develop curriculum to integrate academic enrichment and co-curricular activates; 5) create a collegial and supportive community; 6) establish academic pathways with New Hampshire community colleges in STEM disciplines; 7) build partnerships with community organizations and businesses.

 Over the six-year time period (2010-2016) the program awarded 122 scholarships: 105 academic year awards and 17 one-semester awards. Half of the scholars were in the B.A. Biological Sciences program (35) and the other half in B.S. Computer Information Systems (20) and B.S. Engineering Technology (14) programs. 44% of the scholars were females. While women were overrepresented among Biological Sciences scholars (76%) and highly underrepresented in Engineering Technology (7%), they represented 28% of the CIS scholars, which is two times higher than the proportion of women in the College’s undergraduate computing programs.

More than two thirds of the scholars were transfer students with 50 or more credits transferred in. The program graduated 45 scholars: 33 graduated during the reporting period (2010 – 2016) and 12 scholars graduated by the end of the 2016-2017 academic year.  Of the 33 scholars who graduated during the reporting period 82% started their careers in STEM fields and 12% have pursued masters and doctoral studies in biological sciences and medical field.  Of the 24 scholars who did not complete the program, 9 transferred to other institutions, left their program of study, or became financially non-eligible for the scholarship, and 15 scholars lost their scholarships because of poor academic performance. Of these 15 scholars, 8 withdrew from the College, but 7 have successfully continued in their STEM majors, petitioned to re-enroll in the program, maintained good grades, and got jobs in STEM fields. The rate of students who lost their scholarships has steadily decreased, from 29% at the end of the first year to 21% after year 2, and 10%, and 4% in years 3, 4, 5, and 6. In its last year, the program registered the highest cohort GPA of 3.44 in both semesters and the highest retention rate of 96%. Scholars were very engaged in the College community through their participation as orientation and peer assistant leaders, presenters at the UNH Undergraduate Research Conference, technical lab assistants, and tutors in the Center for Academic Enrichment.

Intellectual Merit

The UNHM-SST program contributed to the development of four courses that advocate and prepare students for STEM majors and careers: First Year Seminar with focus on STEM (1 credit), Shared Learning (2 credits) to emphasize peer learning practices, Exploring Your Career Options (1 credit), and Internship and Career Planning (1 credit). These courses were initially developed as cohort courses to form the learning community curriculum for the UNHM-SST scholars. To structure more support for STEM students at UNH Manchester, one faculty mentor created a Winter Science Symposium for STEM majors, modeled after the University-wide Undergraduate Research Conference that is organized in spring.

 Broader Impacts

The most significant result is the institutional change that the project has inspired. UNH Manchester has continued to allocate funds to support STEM scholarships for incoming students with $2,000 awards, renewable each year for recipients that meet a minimum GPA of 2.8. Candidates are considered based on stated interest in chosen field, prior academic performance, involvement in STEM-related activities, engagement in school or local community, and level of demonstrated need. The institutionally supported STEM scholarship program has similar requirements and opportunities as the NSF-sponsored program.

Three new STEM bachelor's programs have been created at UNH Manchester in Analytics, Biotechnology, and Computer Science in the past two years. STEM scholar faculty mentors participated in developing these programs, which include required internships and capstone experiences. The addition of these STEM majors is reflective of the College commitment to expand STEM education. A significant outcome of this commitment is the creation of STEM educational pathways between the College’s STEM programs and corresponding two-year programs at all seven community colleges in the state.

Increasing support and enrollments in the College’s STEM programs was an important factor in the College space expansion in 2015. The additional 17,000 square feet space allowed the College to launch new STEM programs with a focus on developing local talent based on market needs. The new location includes a robust student commons for collaborative learning and greatly expanded biology and technology labs.
